contents.p: This cedar-wood coffin belonging to a man named Irethoriru was once brilliantly painted, but only traces of its color remain: some blue-green stripes can still be seen behind the right ear and some white cement might have been used to set glass inlays into the central inscription. The coffin is stylistically similar to those made in the 30th dynasty and the early Ptolemaic period, so Irethoriru probably lived during this time. The coffin gives the names of his mother and father, but we know little else about him at this point, other than that he was wealthy enough to afford a coffin made from imported wood.
The texts consist of a version of Book of the Dead Spell 72, followed by a "Nut Spell" derived from Pyramid Text 368.
The coffin of Irethoriru was gifted to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco by Diane B. Wilsley in honor of Alfred S. Wilsley.

Revered one of Osiris, Irethoriru, son of Herirsen, who the lady of the house Tadiusir bore, justified, as a lord of truth who knows how to come out from the hall of two truths.

footnotes.fn: This name should be treated as provisional, since there are no close paralels in Ranke PN and is spelled differently in the two places it occurs--the second being on line 9.
WB III 106.7 for this spelling of xn.ty
According to LGG III p 810, these are underworld beings who appear in other contexts.
This may be a somewhat scrambled second person plural pronoun in which the carver slipped while making the plural strokes.
The name here is usually "Tkm." See 18th dynasty version in P. Nu and Ptolemaic version in P. Turin 1791. Nekau is not otherwise known.
There is a pretty clear modern repair to the coffin lid here where a crack has been filled in, obscuring the glyphs here.
Here, "pw" ("This") is expected, and the "ip" could be a version of the archaic "ipw"--"these."
Here ends Spell 72, in the same location as the 18th Dynasty version. The spell which follows is a Nut spell derived from PT 368 and common on coffins from the Saite period forward.
